results.content:
This course is basically a survey course. The problem is that it covers a wide range of topics (all of which are important for the subject matter), but in the process, the instructor has serious trouble explaining in-depth reasons for WHY something is the way it is. I definitely got a lot out of this course, but I had to wait through a bunch of lectures that covered basics before moving on to the "harder" stuff. I found out 2 things: 
(1)  Watching the basics videos was completely unhelpful. I thought I would glean new information about the basics, like little things I didn't already know because a course like this SHOULD explain things in-depth, even at the beginner stages.
(2) The "harder" sections have the same problem. The depth is not there. You do a project, but only cover 50% of why things are or are not working.
As a last note, I found that the production value of the course was half-*$$ed. Instead of putting in time to make each video focus on the part of the screen we are supposed to be focused on, he just has everything in split view, with the font sizes real big so you can see what he's typing. The instructor doesn't even bother to do minor things, like how the code editor he uses didn't have a plugin installed to correctly highlight SCSS syntax. It would have been simple to install it before the video, or even better, just do it in front of the viewer so they know what's going on on his system.
Overall, the content is both good and bad. The instructor knows his stuff, but he struggles to teach in a way that delivers the promises given at the beginning of the course.

results.content: Explanation not detailed enough. And you weren't properly explaining how the CSS instructions was going to affect the HTML elements in relation to the DOM and centering. Like how float:left makes things effecticely inline-block. And how list-type: none removes the circle thingy. And how setting a width and setting the margin left and right to auto centers the container. Remember this is an introduction project and I could only follow the CSS because I already knew CSS. For someone new to web development, who doesn't understand CSS, a lot of what you did here might look like gibberish to them. But I guess all of this will be covered in the CSS. All I'm saying is a little bit more explanation as to how the CSS are affecting the elements will help.

results.content:
I'm in 4 Full stack developer courses here on Udemy. 

This by FAR is the best one with the most features. I do like some of the others (they had some good projects, and when it was on sale I couldn't pass it up knowing they had them), but this one has well over 20 sections of material, and it's laid out great!

A little about me: I develop for 3 businesses and my Church. I have built 28 WordPress sites (which, this course doesn't have but he has some awesome free WordPress classes anyway), and 26 From-Scratch sites. I've been developing for well over 4 years and I'm still learning a lot from this class.

EDIT: Another important reason to WHY this class is far superior to others is that he includes SOURCE FILES.

I cannot stress enough how painful it is to get a large chunk of some project done that you'll never be able to finish correctly because the API documentation has changed for the 39th time in a 3 day span and the link to make it do what your teacher is doing is somewhere like a needle in a haystack. I just suffered that experience from a different class, which makes me appreciate this more.

2. The lecturer didn't introduce any syntax knowledge for a new framework, just typing on their machine and reading what he was typing. So even you can recite the code about what he have done in the course, you still cannot write a practical new application. And you will feel confused through most of the time in the class. Text Tutorial even did better, at least it will provide what syntax hint you should google.
3. The most disappointed thing is the lecturer didn't provide the introduction of the programming principle for different technologies and  you will never know why you want to use this programming and the corresponding syntax instead of others. 
The most useful part is that this course provide you some hints of the frameworks and provide the confusions that you should google but without telling you some of the key words. So you will take time far more  than the time mentioned in the course to handle a given technique like Meteor, Node, Angular, etc.

results.content:
I enrolled in this course to get a quick overview of the existing web development technologies. There's quite a bit of ground covered here and, probably because of that, the lecturer does not seem to be digging too deep into each framework. That's OK and what I expected. At the same time, I feel there's not enough explanation as to why one framework should be preferred to another and in what situations. For example, in what cases should I choose MongoDB over a traditional SQL database? How does node.js compare with PHP or Django, apart from the developer being able to use the same language for front-end and back-end development? 

Then there are also no exercises. I understand that the students are free to go out and explore on their own after completing each part but giving them some directions would still be useful. In my view, carefully thought-out exercises are an integral part of any proper training course.

All in all, I expect that after completing this course I will have a general idea that such and such technologies exist out there but will not be able to use them unless I undertake a significant amount of my own research and practice.

results.content:
I have been writing code for over 40 years, but have absolutely ZERO experience with webpages. The course covers some pretty basic stuff at times, which I don't always need. However, there are sections where I appreciate the fact that Brad is assuming no previous knowledge.

I would offer one piece of advice; He often just goes off and does something with absolutely no explanation. For example, using the W3 CSS files. At first I was confused by this. Eventually I understood that this is similar to using an "include" to access previously written code (not "reinventing the wheel"). A sentence or two of explanation would have gone a LONG way!

results.content:
Well first of all , I should thank you for this great course, In my opinion which I do my best to be useful for others, I think the title "Full Stack" is a little big for it, because , it depends how you describe this 2 words, let me go deeper, in most part of this course you explain things a little and other parts continues like copy/pasting and I think for a newbie in the end this will not be a profession but only a few code that he knows and nothing more, for example you never explained what exactly is non blocking programming and it's structure , or in angular, you didn't update it to angular 4, and the process was completely useless.
beside all of this, setting up development environment is itself an important topic which you didn't talk about, explaining the features of text editor was also another important subject. in fact subject priority in this course need a little work, for example using css, javascript, mongodb , etc before their specific chapters

I think I can name this course as "Web Development Starter Course" but I recommend everyone who want to be real programmer first start learning fundamentals and design patterns and so on and look at this course as a starter and don't expect to be a high level full stack developer after taking this course
Thank you brad, I'm a fan of you and your videos in youtube and udemy

results.content:
The course covers many topics. The major drawback, though, is that there are not any assignments where the students have to think for themselves and solve problems. 

All course episodes are just instructions/coding along.

If you want a nice overview of all concepts, it's great. But if you really want to learn how to use the different technologies, you would have to make side projects aside from watching the videos.

If learning web programming is as simple as watching someone type or listening to someone read then we dont need any instructor - for the php part there is virtually no explanation on why he did what he did - he created a table and most of the time need a id - why???
what does it do? 
I go to the ftp and there are a list of php files why is it structured that way? 
there is no explanation 
all of these courses are the same showing you the little bit that happens inside the file but no bigger pictures - I guess thats how programmers thinks? In details but not big pictures.
Will i ever find a good web programming course? am i reaching for the moon?
